item.title: Code doesn't execute sequentially
item.dc:creator: @Kattoor Snow_
item.description:
@Kattoor wrote:

fillList had to be a static method, I fixed it in the original post.
This was just an example I wrote in the comment box on the forums to explain what I meant.

I’ve read something about the Java memory model not being sequential consistent. Could this have something to do with it?

–Edit

-sigh-
After testing the above provided code, I noticed it will always output the value: 99.
I’ll just post the code I have in which the issue actually occurs. Note that this is not my code but my teacher’s.
Running this, I often get an index out of bounds exception. So basically the same problem as I specified in my first post, the maakList method is being executed AFTER the threads are started.

[code]public class RunPart3 {
private static final int AMOUNT = 6;

public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException {
    Thread[] attackers = new Thread[AMOUNT];
    int i = 0;
    for (Position position : Position.values()) {
        for (Operation operation : Operation.values()) {
            attackers[i++] = new Thread(new ListAttacker(position, operation));
        }
    }

    ListAttacker.createList();
    System.out.println("Number of elements in the list for attack: " + ListAttacker.getSize() + "\n");
    for (Thread thread : attackers) {
        thread.start();
    }
    
    System.out.println("\nNumber of elements in the list for attack: " + ListAttacker.getSize());
}

}
[/code]

public enum Position { FRONT, MID, BACK }

public enum Operation { REMOVE, ADD }

[code]public class ListAttacker implements Runnable {
private static List numbersList = new ArrayList();
private static Random random = new Random();
private static final int AMOUNT = 100;
private Position position;
private Operation operation;

public ListAttacker(Position position, Operation operation) {
	this.position = position;
	this.operation = operation;
}

public static void createList() {
	for (int i = 0; i < AMOUNT; i++) {
		numbersList.add(random.nextInt());
	}
}

public synchronized static int getSize() {
	return numbersList.size();
}

@Override
public void run() {
	for (int i = 0; i < AMOUNT; i++) {
		synchronized (numbersList) {
			int pos = 0;
			switch (position) {
			case FRONT:
				pos = 0;
				break;
			case MID:
				pos = numbersList.size() / 2;
				break;
			case BACK:
				pos = numbersList.size() - 1;
			}

			try {
				switch (operations) {
				case ADD:
					numbersList.add(pos, random.nextInt());
					break;
				case REMOVE:
					numbersList.remove(pos);
				}
			} catch (Exception e) {
				System.out.println("Problem: " + e + "operation: " + operation
						+ "pos:" + position);
			}
		}
	}
	try {
		Thread.sleep(random.nextInt(50));
	} catch (InterruptedException e) {
		System.out.println(e);
	}
	System.out.println(getClass().getName() + "_" + operation + "_"
			+ position + " ended");
}[/code]

item.title: Code doesn't execute sequentially

@wildskiller wrote:

A.fillList();

This ^ isn’t possible, and the reason the console prints out -1 is because the list size is 0.

item.title: Code doesn't execute sequentially
item.dc:creator: @Kattoor Snow_
item.description:
@Kattoor wrote:

The code below will sometimes print the value -1.
This means the fillList method isn’t being executed before the thread starts.
Is this caused by the JVM trying to optimize the code or am I completely wrong?
Could anyone tell me why this happens? Or give me something to google?
Thanks!

class B {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        A.fillList();
        new Thread(new A()).start();
    }
}

class A implements Runnable {
    private static List<Integer> numbersList = new ArrayList<>();
    public static void fillList() {
        for (int i = 0; i < 100; i++)
            numberList.add(i);
    }
    @Override
    public void run() {
        System.out.println(numbersList.size() - 1);
    }  
}

Read full topic
